Reviews.Title: The POOR REVIEWS are REAL!
Reviews.Author: Bob
Reviews.Content: I saw the reviews but figured only unhappy people write reviews, most of the happy owners don't bother. I was wrong, much of what I read about this camera came to be true. I purchased the Sealife Mini II camera and it did ship quickly (thank you House of Scuba). However, everything went south from there. This is suppose to be a 9MP camera. If that is the case, it must have the bottom of a coke bottle for a lens. Image quality was on par with your average phone camera. NO BETTER. Yes, I too had the same problem with the battery meter going screwy and yes, mine too died while on my vacation. The camera is less than a month old and simply stopped working. Was camera - now brick. Not sure what the issue is with Sealife, the product had so much to offer and filled a perfect niche but it fails to meet even the lowest of marks. Note to Sealife Mgt - If you want to stay in business - you are going to have to do better.The Sealife brick, errrr, I mean camera has been returned. House of Scuba willing took it back. They are a good Amazon retailer. However, I do have to eat a $13.00 postage fee. Life ain't perfect I guess.

Reviews.Title: Poor quality and craftsmanship
Reviews.Author: Scott
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera for my first ever dive trip to Cozumel and ended up being very disappointed.Halfway through my first dive, I noticed that the rubber button for the flash was missing; it had came off somewhere in the water and was lost. But that was the least of my problems.Over the course of 7 days and a total of 14 dives to depths ranging from 20 to 119 ft, the camera's performance was subpar to say the least. On three separate occasions, right in the middle of a dive, the camera suddenly displayed a "card error" message and quit working. I wish I could comment on battery life but it was all over the charts. One minute it would show a full battery charge (with brand new batteries installed), the next it would show the low battery icon, then turn itself off. I'd turn it back on and it would be back to showing a full battery. The video and picture quality were average at best. One of the people in our group was using a Canon Powershot SD1300 IS in a waterproof case and the photos and video from that camera made the Mini II's look like crap! Another person's review likened the image quality to that of a cheap cell phone camera; they're absolutely right. Another person in our group was also using a brand new Mini II and he shares my opinion. Both of us plan on returning our cameras for a refund.UPDATE: I was indeed able to return the Mini II for a refund and instead bought a Canon Powershot 300HS camera and Canon's underwater housing for it. Price-wise, the Canon and the housing cost me the same as the Mini II. Took the 300HS on a 7 day dive trip to Roatan and the quality of the photos and high definition video (unavailable on the Mini II) was outstanding, proving conclusively (in my case anyway) that the Sealife Mini II is a piece of junk.

Reviews.Title: Catastrophic leak on 2nd dive
Reviews.Author: Paul D. Clary "Pinotmaker"
Reviews.Content: The camera is guaranteed to depths of up to 130'.I purchased my first dive camera, a Mini 2, for a dive trip to Roatan.The camera seal failed on the 2nd dive, max depth = 60'.I thought that the batteries needed replacing, but when I opened the door, water dripped out. Batteries still had plenty of charge. Camera was dead.I'm told that SeaLife will cover the camera, but I really don't need a dive camera now that the trip is past.

Reviews.Title: Please consider poor reviews - this camera does not hold up
Reviews.Author: J. Ross
Reviews.Content: We purchased this camera for both snorkeling and SCUBA diving, but have only taken it SCUBA diving once, to a depth of approximately 30 feet. The other 5 times or so we've used it were for snorkeling trips.The camera seemed pretty decent at first; the picture quality wasn't fantastic, per say, but that could be equal parts water clarity and camera quality. But the reason for the negative review is primarily the longevity for this camera; for the price, I certainly would have expected it to last more than 6 times in the water. On our most recent snorkel trip, we noticed water had gotten under the display screen somehow. From the previous time of use to this now problematic one, we hadn't opened the camera or done anything with the memory card. We also hadn't dropped it or left it anywhere it should have been left - it was well taken care of. So, for reasons unknown to us, the seal seems to have broken, and the camera is no longer of any use to us.The way this camera is made is not durable - do not be tempted to purchase it due to it's 'lower' underwater camera price - it is simply not worth the money.

Reviews.Title: Sea Life Mini 2 = Waste of money
Reviews.Author: Christopher Vaught
Reviews.Content: I've returned this camera three times now. First seal broke at 60ft in cold water.Third numerous issues with memory card failing. DO NOT BUY THIS CAMERA.When it works though it is adequate as a document.If your a wreck diver save up for a serious camera housing.If you must have a snapshot type camera get the Lumix or Fuji.

Reviews.Title: Light weight camera
Reviews.Author: chub210
Reviews.Content: The Sealife camera was a gift for my husband who dives and is constantly taking photos.  He raves about it and the fact he doesn't have to use any other water proof container as it comes ready to go.

Reviews.Title: I wasnt impressed
Reviews.Author: wyodoc1
Reviews.Content: I have other sealife cameras and I was hoping this would be of the same calibre.  I was disapointed.I didn't expect it to be a great camera, but it really reminds me of the instamatic 110 cameras of my youth, point and prey.Your choices for modes are underwater or landscape. There is a macro and digital zoom feature, but neither are all that.I had not noticed that you have to pull the SD card and put it in another device to get the photos off, no big deal really, just expected to have a micro USB under the water tight door. So if you are planning to offload the photos, make sure you have a card reader or laptop that will support the card size.  My Lenovo wouldnt accept SD card larger than 2Gb.I found it difficult to read the display when outdoors, making it even tougher to tell if you were actually recording something.The camera is what it is, a very inexpensive camera that does UW.  It is simple to operate.  I will probably bring this one along on my dive trips as a backup to my other sealife camera.

Reviews.Title: Very poor low light capabilities
Reviews.Author: instructor
Reviews.Content: Unless you are outdoors on an average to sunny day picture quality is poor. The flash works only within a few feet.The same poor picture goes for the video indoors. Set the camera on land or water, pictures have a red hue.Have not used the camera on a dive yet, but with such poor low light and I'm talking about average indoor daylight that works with my other point and shoot camera's, I can't see this camera working very well.

Reviews.Title: Poor service and quality
Reviews.Author: Luke
Reviews.Content: This is my first review after many purchases on amazon. I have never ordered a product so poor. The camera takes substandard quality images and stopped working after two dives. I have tried to contact Sealife with no response, and even sent in the camera only to have it returned in the exact same condition, non functional. If you are interested in basic underwater photography, get a simple point and shoot and its matching underwater case. It will be a little bit more cost, but it will work.  You get what you pay for.

Reviews.Title: Disappointed occasional diver
Reviews.Author: Julie A. Hoover
Reviews.Content: My wife purchased the Sealife Mini II for me for Father's Day 2011, on sale.  I played with it a little in a swimming pool and on land.  Finally was able to book a diving trip to Kauai in June of 2012.  We left for the vacation on Father's Day of 2012.  (The camera has a 1 year warranty).  I knew of the short battery life and had plenty of AAA batteries with me and the batteries lasted through each dive with no problem. I also had a 4 gb SDHC memory card.  Our first dive worked ok.  On the second dive, I got a "memory full" message, then a card error message.  Well, I was surprised that I would have used up 4 gigs of memory, so I ran  out and purchased a 16 gb SDHC card.  Checked that the new card would work and got ready for our next dive.  The next day on our next dive, I took a few pictures and made a short video, when I got a full memory message again.  Since I had only a few pics, I decided to just reformat the card while I was still underwater (one of the nice features of the camera), so I lost those pictures.  Then the camera gave me a "card error" message.  So, no more pictures on that dive.  Checked the camera once we were out of the water, everything seemed to be working alright again.  Went down for our final dive and immediately got a card error message.  All in all, out of four dives, I got one short video clip and about 20 pictures.  I was really looking forward to getting a chance to use this camera on a dive (we are occasional divers, one trip every year or two) and we are extremely disappointed in this camera.I admit that it is an easy camera to use, but found that the pictures it did take (9 Megapixels) were really not a great quality and the video is so-so.  I have contacted the retailer that I purchased it from, and he has promised to try to help me, but I am afraid that I may be stuck with this less than perfect camera because I have had it for more than a year.  I will not take a chance with this camera on another dive (October cruise to Mexico).  I am thinking of a "Go Pro" camera system instead.Chris Hoover, Bakersfield, CA

Reviews.Title: SeaLife Mini II
Reviews.Author: Superfly
Reviews.Content: Contrary to some of the reviews I read, I thought the Mini II totally delivered as promised.  I had no problems with any type of leakage and used the camera to depth of about 30 ft.  The colors were good especially closer to the surface, at deeper depth, SeaLife recommends the Digital Pro Flash, which I will get for this camera.I did use it with the wide angle lens, that made a big difference vs. without, recommend that accessory for all Mini II users.  Overall it's a nice durable camera, and for the money it was a good deal and got some great results.

Reviews.Title: Had no problems!
Reviews.Author: MR "MR"
Reviews.Content: I actually had absolutely no problems with this camera.  It sounds like the other person got a lemon.There were a few times I could not see the screen properly underwater (so I was literally pointing and shooting) but otherwise this thing is as sturdy as a tank.  It does sink, so getting a floatation device is a must; at the very least some bright neon tape would be helpful. (I almost lost it in a reef and my dive instructor had to go looking for it).  This is not a super high quality camera, but it will allow you to bring home memories from your vacation.Because of how rugged this thing was, I was never afraid of breaking it.  I simply rinsed it after every dive and made sure it was completely dry before transferrinng any images.The fish and turtle images are two that I took with this camera!

Reviews.Title: Not waterproof!
Reviews.Author: Pen Name
Reviews.Content: Believe the bad reviews about this camera not being waterproof. I had my camera for only one day and used it once in 3 feet of water in a swimming pool. The pictures and movies that I took were awesome, but it only lasted about 10 minutes before the screen turned white and then turned off. Behind the screen and lens were filled with water. When I opened the battery housing door later on, water poured out of from inside. Luckily my SD card was not damaged and I have the pictures and video clips.I'm returning it for a refund and looking into a more expensive brand.

Reviews.Title: Worst camera ever!
Reviews.Author: Erika
Reviews.Content: The item arrived on time for our dive vacation to Belize.The camera however is a piece of garbage. We didn't take the camera for the first drive to just get acclimated with diving again. The camera was used during the 2nd dive at about 60 ft. When we got back up to the boat, there was water in the casing - the seal had leaked. We purchased the camera for this special dive trip and used it once and it broke!This camera can be used for dives up to 130 feet. We couldn't even test out the camera at the Blue Hole which is where we wanted to use it.

Reviews.Title: Major Dissapointment
Reviews.Author: D. Sieputowski
Reviews.Content: Bought for Caribbean dive pictures. didn't expect great pictures but just something reasonable. Camera flooded during very first dive.Major disappointment given where I was diving.Returned to Sealife,and,with outstanding customer service,was promptly exchanged. A bit too late for me however.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Ryan Roeser
Reviews.Content: I have had this camera for 3 diving seasons now and have logged over 30 dives with it.  I have had it to 105ft and have not had any problems with it at all.  I think it takes good photos and I was so thankful to have it with me when I got up close to a 6ft long paddle fish. It's a lot of fun to have and it helps to preserve some of your fun diving memories.  Very easy to use. Not sure why other people have given it bad reviews, my guess is user error.  I would definitely recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Good camera for the price!
Reviews.Author: A. E. Lamb
Reviews.Content: I had no problems with battery life in this camera.  It comes with lithium batteries and we only used 1 set our whole vacation...that included 2 scuba dives and a snorkeling session.  There was one time I turned it on and it said my battery was low.  But I turned it off and when I turned it back on later it was back to full battery life.Sometimes picture quality isn't great, but generally is good.  No problems with leaking and we went up to 70 feet deep while diving.  My only problem was it switched over to internal memory during a dive and I didn't know how to switch it back and the interal memory fills up quickly.  So be warned there is both internal memory of like 24 or so pictures and the SD card memory!Definitely well worth the price!

Reviews.Title: Would recommend a better wrist  wrap.
Reviews.Author: Marji  McCready
Reviews.Content: Great pics and fairly easy operation, but the wrist strap is not adjustable and some free-diving had to happen when the camera has fallen off wrist during dive

Reviews.Title: Waste of money-Don't Buy
Reviews.Author: Amy
Reviews.Content: Horrible camera. Same problems everyone else mentioned, it was junk from day one with subpar pictures and glitchy battery indicator and then finally commited underwater suicide by leaking and destroying entire camera. Worthless.

Reviews.Title: SeaLife Mini II helped me document my adventure!
Reviews.Author: Embodily
Reviews.Content: The SeaLife Mini II is a bulkier camera but its bulk provides extreme durability and security to your valuable pictures. It allowed me to capture some amazing pictures for my first and following snorkeling trips during my month-long+ trip in the islands of Thailand. The reviews on Amazon had me worried about possible leakage of the salt water into the camera but I shouldn't have been concerned. For over 8 snorkel and kayak day-trips, I only required 1 set of batteries. I bought the 8GB memory card for my trip and it never filled up and I took thousands of pictures. The included wrist strap was excellent for securely holding the camera to my wrist while I swam. There is a small delay in the shutter so with the quicker fish it was more of a challenge to capture them but I found after a while a method to take several pictures in a row while trying to hold the camera steady under the water usually produced at least one clear shot. Towards the end of my trip I did find that the lens of the camera looked cloudy and some pictures reflected this. The locking mechanism on the camera which covers the battery and memory card from the water is complicated at first to open however after a few tries it becomes second nature. Having the memory card USB reader is fantastic for quickly uploading shots to see the beautiful memories you captured. The fact that the camera has both a land and a water setting is really helpful. Though I did find that sometimes I would forget to change my setting from water to land when I would come up to the surface but my pictures still tended to turn out well. I had a hard time with the flash on the camera. I couldn't really figure out when I was supposed to use it - sometimes it worked but sometimes it would blur everything and even seemed to scare the fish away. I appreciated the battery-save mode with the camera - it would turn off after no pictures were taken for a while.Overall I would recommend this camera for underwater pictures and for being an almost indestructible camera for action adventures. I loved not worrying about when my camera fell out of my bag on the boat and when it hit the kayak by accident. The lighting does affect the pictures and especially whether you have a steady hand but once you master that the pictures you can take are endless.I cannot speak to how this camera compares to the more expensive SeaLife Reefmaster or Pro but for a basic intro underwater camera it more than served its purpose!Pictures can speak more than words so check out some of the great pictures that were taken with this SeaLife Mini II!I know I am really excited for my next water adventure and being able to document the experience!Suggestions for improvement: Add a lens cover that you could flip manually so when you want to store the camera the lens doesn't bump up against a finger or something. Something to clean the lens of the fog from water or salt deposits. I used my sunglass cloth and that helped a lot but I'm sure there could be something better. Would be nice if it could be a little less thick so that it could fit comfortably in a pants or short pocket easier. Perhaps also a viewfinder in addition to the screen - I found when I was taking pictures and it was really bright I would have difficulty seeing the screen to tell what I was taking a picture of and wouldn't be able to see the results until I had uploaded the pictures to my computer.I did not pay for this product but I do not believe that I let that color my review. I selected this product after doing careful research about the best products of its type and requested a sample to test in my own practice.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for the price but need flash
Reviews.Author: Catherine McDermott
Reviews.Content: We bought this camera for my son to use on his first dive trip to Anguilla.  He got some great pictures.  The only problem is light.  If you are going to take really good clear pictures with any color you need to get the flash attachment and red filter.  But overall great camera.

Reviews.Title: Stay away from SeaLife Cameras!
Reviews.Author: Tracy V
Reviews.Content: This is the second seaLife camera I've purchased and you'd think I'd have learned after the first.  Both times, the cameras took OK pictures but needed lots of editing on land.  The first camera flooded after on my second dive trip.  I assumed it was because I wasn't careful enough when changing batteries (after EVERY dive).  After purchasing the second one I was very careful to use the brush, check the seal etc...every time I opened it and it still flooded 3 days into my dive.  It's cheap but not worth it.  Next time I'm going with a water resistant camera inside a sealed housing.

Reviews.Title: Great for capturing memories at a reasonable cost
Reviews.Author: Amazon Reviewer
Reviews.Content: Considering price and our needs, this camera does what we expected and wanted.  If you are looking for magazine quality photos, consider a much more expensive camera.  We wanted something that went further than the disposable film cameras (15 ft) as my husband was going to dive the Great Barrier Reef.  This product states it goes to 130 feet.  The digital feature was a bonus as he did not have to wait long to see the results.  After viewing the pictures, I noticed the exposure was not as good.  However, you have to consider that he was at depth and you lose color.  We found the video to be far more interesting though as you could hear sounds.  There is an underwater and land option on the camera to account for lighting conditions so you have to remember to switch it when taking pictures in either situation.  My husband took pictures while going canyoning in New Zealand and they looked good.The only issue my husband encountered was the battery life which I had read from user reviews.  I spoke with Sea Life today and they indicated that it was recommended that lithium instead of alkaline batteries be used.  It makes sense as the camera has to work harder to capture the image due to the low light conditions.  The technician I spoke with was extremely helpful and offered to send me lithium batteries to try out before sending it back in for repair.  For more inforamtion, check out their website about the product specification ([..]).Overall, we like the product.  If you consider the cost of a disposable cameras (the camera iteslf and processing), this camera will eventually cost us less in the long run. The quality of the pictures is on par with a point and shoot so it is good for capturing memories.  We also plan to use it for other water related activities (e.g. snorkeling, tubing, jet skiing, etc) and will probably use it for skiing (using the land option).  This way, we do not have to worry about my regular point and shoot getting damaged as it is shock proof.

Reviews.Title: Junk is what you get with SeaLife Mini II
Reviews.Author: Farrokh R. Tabatabai, PhD
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera for using it outdoors and diving and on trips and it is the most awful camera I have ever owned to date. After every few pictures it requires new batteries and picture quality is as bad as throw-away cameras (their 9mp is more like 9kp). The battery indicator shows fully charged but when you push the shutter button, the camera turns off. I haven't used it diving yet, but if it won't work on land, what's the point of taking it under water?Relatively speaking it is inexpensive; but cheap is what you get when you waste your money on this camera. I contacted the seller which were very nice but I had it too long to return it to them (I did not use it soon enough to find out how bad this thing is).I don't think the factory will do anything since I sent them an e-mail and never heard from them. So, save your money for something that will work when you want it to work. I wish Amazon rating system had a "junk' before any stars since this gadget would get the rating "JUNK".

Reviews.Title: first underwater camera,
Reviews.Author: Randy Lustig
Reviews.Content: This little camera does all it is advertized to do and more. It is my first digital underwater camera. Perfect.

Reviews.Title: Perfect point and shoot
Reviews.Author: Kathryn
Reviews.Content: We bought this camera before any reviews had been published so we didn't know what to expect. We were so pleasantly surprised! Its so easy to clean and use, so convenient, and takes great pictures and videos! The batteries last an entire dive trip! No need to change the batteries mid trip! Its definitely not a professional camera, and won't take pictures like the serious underwater cameras will, but for our recreational purposes and the price its just perfect. There is only one O ring and takes no maintenance like other cameras. It has a scuba and snorkeling function. We've found that diving in 50 feet or less, the snorkeling function is better than the diving function. The pictures are less pink. We couldn't be happier however, and it was worth the cost! We love it!

Reviews.Title: Great Company
Reviews.Author: drrucks
Reviews.Content: We were on vacation ready to use our new Sealife Mini II camera on our first scuba dive and unfortunately the camera malfunctioned and was not usable.  We corresponded with the Sealife company immediately and we were told that they would send us a shipping label to send back the camera free of charge.  Within a matter of days we were sent the label, we sent back the camera, and were promptly sent a brand new camera at no charge!  Wow, That's what I call GREAT customer service!

ProductInfo.Features:
Image Sensor: 9.0 mega pixel CMOS image sensor
Color: 24-bit color (RGB)Image Resolution: 9mp (3472x2604)Picture file format: JPEG
Movie Resolution: VGA (640x480) at 30 frames per second
Video file format: MJPEG (.AVI)
ProductInfo.Name: SeaLife Mini II Underwater Shock & Waterproof Digital Camera
